reviewText: About me:  I am a high intermediate, low advanced exerciser.  I own about 60 workout DVDs right now, with many more to acquire in the future!I've done and LOVED Stephanie Vitorino's "Ultimate Body Shaper" workout.  I would do the entire DVD, the warm-up, both 30 minute workouts and the cooldown (AND abs afterwards).  That workout was fun, challenging, super effective and, when I finished, it was all I could do to drag myself upstairs to the shower!  When I finally tired of that workout (and it took months until I was ready to put it away), I immediately wanted more of that intensity and reached for Body Target 60.But this workout is much, much MUCH less intense than UBS.  I actually was initially disappointed with this one.  The workout is structured accordingly:  1 30-minute cardio/strength interval workout and 3 10-minute toning add-ons, 1 for upper body, 1 for butt and lower body and 1 for core.  I of course do the entire 60 minute workout.First, what I love:  Stephanie!  I first noticed her in the background of Firm workouts, a Star Trainers DVD and a Prevention abs workout that I have.  She is wonderful on UBS as the lead and is even more wonderful on this DVD.  I will definitely purchase more of her programs in the future!  I also love the music in this, and the DVD is tip-top quality. The 10-minute butt routine is also a good one.  The moves are original and deceptively simple.  I do it after the 30-minute workout, and my lower body was burning!  :-)  I felt this not just in my butt, but also my thighs, hip and calves.  Nice! The arm workout is also strong, though the very first move - single, slow, multi-directional arm raises on each arm individually - get a little boring quickly.What I personally needed to change: The cardio in the cardio-strength interval workout (30 min.) wasn't enough.  It didn't really get my heartrate up, and yes, I was putting myself into it. It seems that just when my heartrate might have started to climb, it was over and time to move into a strength move.  I've actually gotten around this by doing 10 minutes of more intense cardio BEFORE this workout.  That made this workout much more challenging. I also increased the muscle fatigue by speeding up the VERY slow kettlebell swings that are done, and by pulsing the raised leg instead of holding it static.  Whew! Now THAT's a workout!  :-) II also wanted more abwork in the 10-minute core workout.  There are a lot of planks, side bends, back work, etc., but you don't hit the front of the abs until the last few seconds.  Just when you feel the burn...It's over!  I'd rather work the front of my abs more than anything else!All in all, it's a fun, effective, satisfying workout that is easy to tweak a bit to raise/lower to your personal level.  Good job Stephanie!
summary: A Little "Lite" for Me, But I Easily Tweaked It To My Level

reviewText: Stephanie is a great trainer.  She's motivational without going overboard.  The moves are new and she really makes you want to do the dvd again.  Definitely not boring.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I only got through the first 10 minutes of this workout before I had to quit.What I did of the workout was ok --- I consider myself at an intermediate level of fitness and this seemed like it would work for me.That said, I could not get past the instructor's voice --- she sounds like she is nervous/trembly when she talks and it just makes me feel nervous and jumpy listening to it.  I have quite an extensive collection of workout DVDs that I've kept and more that I've tried and not kept and this is the first one that made me quit within 10 minutes because I just couldn't take any more of the instructor's voice.  Rather harsh, I know, so I'll say that other than that, she seems great and others will probably get a good workout.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ultimate body shaper was my first experience with Stephanie Vitorino.  I really enjoyed the exercises, and Stephanie as an instructor.  So, I tried body target 60.  Stephanie is still an upbeat and interesting instructor with pretty good cueing even the first time doing it.  Set was plain, but nice.  I like that the back up exercisers were really students from her classes, and not the same fitness models you see over and over again in other workout videos.  I did work up a sweat, but not as much as with ultimate body shaper.  I agree with the reviewer that said not enough cardio and adding 10 minutes on your own before starting this workout would be good.  But then we're looking at over 70 minutes of a workout and most days I don't have that much time.  I will definitely keep it in the rotation, but probably won't turn to it quite as often as her other video, or my other favorites.
summary: good workout but not quite as good as her ultimate body shaper
Title: N/A

reviewText: Body Target 60 is a tough, but enjoyable workout. I didn't get Stephanie's first DVD, however, love her workouts on Exercise TV.  This workout Stephanie seems the most comfortable I've seen her in front of the camera. Her cueing is right on & she clearly explains each movement.  I love the incorporation of balance work throughout this workout. You need two sets of weights, light & heavy plus a mat.Body Target 60 gives the following options on the main menu:- Total Body  60 min.- Cardio Sculpt 30 min- Arms Shaped 10 min.- Butt Firmed 10 min.- Abs Defined 10 min.The Total Body (Cardio Scuplt, Arms Shaped, Butt Firmed, Abs Defined) is about 5 minutes over an hour because it includes a cool down.Cardio Sculpt alternates cardio intervals with sculpting intervals.  Stephanie begins with a starter move and adds on to up the intensity.  Cardio moves used in the Cardio Sculpt include; Squat hops side to side, V-Step, arms down legs thrust back (plank position) pull legs in & stand, side step with knee raise - these are the starter moves.  The variations to the starter movements definately increase the heart rate.  I do wish the cardio was a tad bit longer/difficult to keep HR up a little longer.Sculpting movements in CS include; Rear lunges, shoulder raises, kettlebell swings w/ tricep extension, arm moves across body working bicep, one leg forward hinge over - back rows alternated with backward swing (working tricep), curtsy squat with lateral arm raise, legs together & squat with both hands together holding weights to one side - wood chop. She incorporates balance into these moves, and they are TOUGH!The final section of Cardio Sculpt, Stephanie moves to mat. Pushups, side planks, tricep pushups, & crunches just to name a few. My only complaint is the cardio intervals....I wish they were a little longer/more intense. Just a personal preference. I do realize this is more of a sculpting workout ; )To keep some element of surprise when you do the workout, I will briefly describe the 10 min. sections.ARMS SHAPED -  I love the work on this! Stephanie gets hard core with some of the shoulder work & pushups. One version of pushups she does is a pike pushup - OUCH! She does bicep curls with tricep raises and MORE pushups!!!!BUTT FIRMED -  She begins with chair pose and adds leg taps. Explosive lunges, then on hands & knees - weight between calf and hamstring, press up with glutes. Still down on mat, kick out to the side (working the glute staying on ground - burns!).ABS DEFINED -  Stephanie begins standing, explaining how to correctly engage your core. It was actually very helpful. Plank position & variations of (tough stuff in this), supermans, & some oblique work.This workout is incredible!! Body Target 60 is INTENSE thanks to the creative variations on basic moves plus the addition of balance work. Stephanie does an awesome job on this workout, it's actually fun.  This is a great workout for intermediate to advanced exercisers, as she offers modifications for intermediate. I highly recommend this workout!!!Please let me know if you have any questions or comments  =)

reviewText: Stephanie does not disappoint.  She has all the right moves and GREAT music too!  I was jumping around, lifting weights and before I knew it I was in the zone.  This isn't a hard core workout, but you will feel it when you are through.My only wish is that her 6round slim down was on dvd.

reviewText: I was familiar with Stephanie Vitorino, but never tried any of her workouts until this past year.  She has quickly become on of my all time favorite instructors!Body Target 60 consists of a 30 minute cardio sculpting workout, also called Total Target.  There are also three Target add-ons, one for the butt, arms and core, each about 10 minutes.  You can choose the 30 minute total Target, add on a 10 minute Target or add them all for a 60 minute workout.Stephanie is joined by Michelle and Carla, who shows modifications.  Mainly for the higher impact and more advanced moves. I really appreciate this as I don't care for high impact moves whatsoever.  Many instructors include a modifier, which is nice as it makes their workouts doable by more people of various levels.  I personally have steered away from instructors who don't include a modifier.I like Stephanie's approach to weight training, she uses a lot of compound moves and incorporates functional fitness into her workouts.  As I age, I am realizing the importance of this training and include this into my own workouts along with traditional strength training and kettlebell training.  I feel Stephanie does this well, her style also reminds me a lot of the Firm which I have been a fan of for many years.  Stephanie herself has appeared as a backgrounder in several of the newer Firm workouts.Some of the weight moves include reverse lunges with shoulder raise adding an optional kick, a kettlebell type swing with a overhead tricep press, squat with woodchops, a deadlift type move with alternating shoulder presses, etc.  Some of these moves are layers, you start with one move then gradually add on to it.  However many layers you add is entirely up to you.  I also like the fact that many of the moves incorporate core and balance challenges.  The cardio moves are pretty athletic in nature, nothing too complex.  V steps into plyo jumps, weighted burpees (weights are optional), knee lifts into power hops to name a few.  I like the variety that this workout offers, and if you don't get enough you can always add extra with one or more of the 10 minute targets.I like Stephanie as an instructor, she is clear and displays great form.  She is pleasant and encouraging along the way as well.  One other reviewer has commented on her voice, I have heard similar comments.  While I understand where these commments come from, Stephanie's voice doesn't bother me at all, I think she has a very clear manner of speaking and a pleasant voice.Minimal equipment is also required for this workout, which is nice.  You only need a couple sets of weights, a lighter set and a heavier set.  I used a range of 5 to 10 pound dumbells.  I would say this workout is suitable for intermediate to advanced exercisers.  Beginners would probably manage with very light weights and by following the modifier.Overall, this is a great workout and one I highly recommend. I rate this 4 and a half stars.
summary: Functional fitness workout with a nice variety!
